greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle read by rows: T(n,k) is the number of Dyck paths of semilength k such that the area between the x-axis and the path is n (n>=0; 0<=k<=n).
comment: Column sums give the Catalan numbers (A000108).
Sums along falling diagonals give A005169.
link: Joerg Arndt and Alois P. Heinz, Rows n = 0..140, flattened
formula: G.f.: F(x,y) satisfies F(x,y) = 1 / (1 -  x*y * F(x, x^2*y) ).
example: Column k=4 corresponds to the following 14 paths (dots denote zeros):
There are no paths with weight < 4, one with weight 4, none with weight 5, 3 with weight 6, etc., therefore column k=4 is
Row n=8 is [0, 0, 0, 0, 3, 0, 5, 0, 1], the corresponding paths of weight=8 are:
maple: b:= proc(x, y, k) option remember;
seq(seq(T(n, k), k=0..n), n=0..20);  # _Alois P. Heinz_, Mar 29 2014
mathematica: b[x_, y_, k_] := b[x, y, k] = If[y<0 || y>x || k<0, 0, If[x == 0, If[k == 0, 1, 0], b[x-1, y-1, k-y+1/2] + b[x-1, y+1, k-y-1/2]]]; T[n_, k_] := b[2*k, 0, n]; Table[ Table[T[n, k], {k, 0, n}], {n, 0, 20}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Feb 18 2015, after _Alois P. Heinz_ *)
program: rvec(V) = { V=Vec(V); my(n=#V); vector(n, j, V[n+1-j] ); }
print_triangle(V)= { my( N=#V ); for(n=1, N, print( rvec( V[n]) ) ); }
xref: Sequences obtained by particular choices for x and y in the g.f. F(x,y) are: A000108 (F(1, x)), A143951 (F(x, 1)), A005169 (F(sqrt(x), sqrt(x))),  A227310 (1+x*F(x, x^2), also 2-1/F(x, 1)), A239928 (F(x^2, x)), A052709 (x*F(1,x+x^2)), A125305 (F(1, x+x^3)), A002212 (F(1, x/(1-x))).
results.author: _Joerg Arndt_, Mar 29 2014
